resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.summary: [C++] Unary kernels can leave uninitialized data under null entries

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description:
We've started seeing Valgrind in our R tests. I did some digging through the commits and found that these errors started when https://github.com/apache/arrow/commit/0d979bf0cbb10e4977c99a542c266134604e72a5 was merged (ARROW-12575).

As far as I know, this is the first use of {{negate_checked}} in R, so that is the likely culprit, though I haven't been able to match the error outputs to the {{negate_checked}} code directly.

Here's the first failure: https://dev.azure.com/ursacomputing/crossbow/_build/results?buildId=4805&view=logs&j=0da5d1d9-276d-5173-c4c4-9d4d4ed14fdb&t=d9b15392-e4ce-5e4c-0c8c-b69645229181&l=2942

comments.body: If we do have a patch release, we will need to address this before the patch release is made. We could look into disabling the tests that it complains about (on CRAN), but given the number of errors, that would likely be a large number of them.

I agree. I am not able to reproduce any errors for *negate* nor *negate_checked* from the C++/Python side. I did added boilerplate code to support unary arithmetic kernels so I do not think the error is the kernel operation itself. Also, not sure if this may be something in the R bindings. I will sit down tonight and investigate the PR carefully.
I would be curious if the error also occurs if *negate* is used in R instead of *negate_checked*. This might help to narrow down if its a kernel issue or boilerplate issue.**

Testing that should be as easy as changing [https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/r/R/expression.R#L118] to use `negate` and then running the valgrind check ([https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/docker-compose.yml#L1057-L1058)]

LMK if anything goes wrong in that process — it should just work, but it's certainly possible for things to go wonky.
We don't need this for a patch release because ARROW-12575 was merged after 4.0, so this is not a bug in 4.0.

During my investigation I made some observations:
 # These runs make use of multiple threads (Line 1981 of the Azure log), multiple runs trigger the errors in different order (race condition?)
 # The first error of "Thread 2" (Line 1994 of Azure log) corresponds to the use of *FnOnce*
 # The comments of *FnOnce* state that invoking this class with a default constructor will result in a segmentation fault, [https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/cpp/src/arrow/util/functional.h#L87-L93]

This brings me to think that adding the unary compute function infrastructure is triggering a previously hidden bug.

Again, I am still investigating this.
Looking more carefully at the logs, most Valgrind errors are triggered in functions that make use of a *MemoryPool* of sorts.
Does this still fail? Can someone post a log of CI test results? The link in the issue description doesn't work anymore.

here's the log [^valgrind-log-2021-06-10.txt] 
one of the many errors is https://dev.azure.com/ursacomputing/crossbow/_build/results?buildId=6471&view=logs&j=0da5d1d9-276d-5173-c4c4-9d4d4ed14fdb&t=d9b15392-e4ce-5e4c-0c8c-b69645229181&l=3804

[~pachamaltese] did you intend to upload that file somewhere? I don't see it attached to the ticket.

It would also be ideal if you could copy/paste the output here (edited to the critical valgrind errors only) so that one doesn't need to click through to another file to see what's going on.

It still fails, I have looked into it but have not been able to find the issue. To give some context, the negative kernel in C++ (ARROW-11950) was resolved by me. This was the first scalar unary kernel so I had to add additional functionality to support it, refer to [https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/10113]

Also, I am curious if the source of this error is due to tests that use "-NaN".

trying again, here's the log just for the docker step, which is where the errors appear
 [^valgrind-log-2021-06-10-docker-step-only.txt]

[~pachamaltese] Are you seeing something problematic in the build step? What's going on there? That's not the important / helpful part of the error. 

Here is an example of the kinds of output you should be looking for (and contributing with these tickets that you make):

{code}
> test_check("arrow", reporter = arrow_reporter)

[... many (~ 11045) similar valgrind errors]

[ FAIL 0 | WARN 6 | SKIP 57 | PASS 3839 ]
Warning message:
In system("timedatectl", intern = TRUE) :
  running command 'timedatectl' had status 1
> 
==3131== 
==3131== HEAP SUMMARY:
==3131==     in use at exit: 318,218,757 bytes in 61,489 blocks
==3131==   total heap usage: 3,562,658 allocs, 3,501,169 frees, 2,690,774,195 bytes allocated

Found Valgrind errors
{code}

I am running the following configurations:
 * using **negate** instead of **negate_checked**
 * disabling signed NaN tests

Will report back as soon as these complete.
Thanks
ARROW-13039 is about the {{Rf_errorcall}} issues (at least some of them).

Using the *negate* kernel did not produced an error but *negate_checked* did. The differences in the checked variant is that it emits an invalid status for unsigned integers and applies explicit casts to the signed integral variant.

Here is a snippet of the first errors triggerred:
{code:java}
